<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Stock Performance Graph
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The graph shows the Company&#146;s cumulative shareholder returns over the period from June&nbsp;20, 2012, the date Burger King common stock
	was listed on the NYSE, to December&nbsp;31, 2016. The graph reflects total shareholder returns for Burger King from June&nbsp;20, 2012 to December&nbsp;12, 2014, and for the Company from December&nbsp;15, 2014 to December&nbsp;31, 2016.
	December&nbsp;12, 2014 was the last day of trading on the NYSE of Burger King common stock and December&nbsp;15, 2014 was the first day of trading on the NYSE and TSX of the Company&#146;s common shares. The graph shows combined Burger King and the
	Company shareholder returns because the Company has less than three years of history as a public company. The following graph depicts the total return to shareholders from June&nbsp;20, 2012 through December&nbsp;31, 2016, relative to the
	performance of the Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s 500 Index and the Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s Restaurant Index, a peer group. The graph assumes an investment of $100 in Burger King common stock and each index on June&nbsp;20, 2012 and the
	reinvestment of dividends paid since that date. The stock price performance shown in the graph is not necessarily indicative of future price performance.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT" ALIGN="CENTER">
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2017/02/17/0001193125-17-048122_G294138G18S23.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<A NAME="FIS_FINANCIAL_DATA"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<A NAME="D294138D10K_HTM_TX294138_10">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;6.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Selected Financial Data
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Unless the context otherwise requires,
	all references to the &#147;Company&#148;, &#147;we&#148;, &#147;us&#148; or &#147;our&#148; refer to Restaurant Brands International Inc. and its subsidiaries, collectively.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	All references to &#147;$&#148; or &#147;dollars&#148; in this report are to the currency of the United States unless otherwise indicated.
	All references to Canadian dollars or C$ are to the currency of Canada unless otherwise indicated.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following tables present our
	selected historical consolidated financial and other data as of the dates and for each of the periods indicated. The selected historical financial data as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015 and for 2016, 2015 and 2014 have been
	derived from our audited consolidated financial statements and notes thereto included in this report. The selected historical financial data as of December&nbsp;31, 2014, December&nbsp;31, 2013 and December&nbsp;31, 2012 and for 2013 and 2012 have
	been derived from our audited consolidated financial statements and notes thereto, which are not included in this report. The other operating data for 2016, 2015 and 2014 have been derived from our internal records.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	26
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage27"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D294138D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The selected consolidated financial and other operating data presented below contain all normal
	recurring adjustments that, in the opinion of management, are necessary to present fairly our financial position and results of operations as of and for the periods presented. The selected historical consolidated financial and other operating data
	included below and elsewhere in this report are not necessarily indicative of future results. The information presented below should be read in conjunction with
<I>
	&#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results
	of
</I>
<I>
	Operations&#148;
</I>
	in Part&nbsp;II, Item&nbsp;7 and &#147;
<I>
	Financial Statements and Supplementary
</I>
<I>
	Data
</I>
	&#148; in Part&nbsp;II, Item&nbsp;8 of this report.
</P>

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	On December&nbsp;12, 2014, we acquired Tim Hortons. Statement of operations data and other financial data include TH results from the acquisition date through December&nbsp;28, 2014, the end of Tim Hortons 2014 fiscal
	year. Balance sheet data includes TH data as of December&nbsp;28, 2014.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(b)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Amount includes $16.4&nbsp;million of integration costs for 2016. Amount includes $116.7&nbsp;million of TH transaction and restructuring costs and $0.5&nbsp;million of acquisition accounting impact on cost of sales for
	2015. Amount includes $125.0&nbsp;million of TH transaction and restructuring costs, $11.8&nbsp;million of acquisition accounting impact on cost of sales and $290.9&nbsp;million of net losses on derivatives for 2014. Amount includes
	$26.2&nbsp;million of global portfolio realignment project costs for 2013. Amount includes $30.2&nbsp;million of global portfolio realignment project costs and $27.0&nbsp;million of business combination agreement expenses for 2012.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

	27
</P>

<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D294138D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(c)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	For 2016, 2015 and 2014, the diluted earnings per share calculation assumes conversion of 100% of the Partnership exchangeable units under the &#147;if converted&#148; method. Accordingly, the numerator is also adjusted
	to include the earnings allocated to the holders of noncontrolling interests.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(d)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Comparable sales growth and system-wide sales growth are analyzed on a constant currency basis, which means they are calculated by translating prior year results at current year average exchange rates, to remove the
	effects of currency fluctuations from these trend analyses. We believe these constant currency measures provide a more meaningful analysis of our business by identifying the underlying business trends, without distortion from the effect of foreign
	currency movements.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(e)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Unless otherwise stated, comparable sales growth and system-wide sales growth are presented on a system-wide basis, which means they include Company restaurants and franchise restaurants. Franchise sales represent sales
	at all franchise restaurants and are revenues to our franchisees. We do not record franchise sales as revenues; however, our royalty revenues are calculated based on a percentage of franchise sales. See
<I>
	&#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and
	Analysis of Financial
</I>
<I>
	Condition and Results of Operations &#151; Key Business
</I>
<I>
	Metrics&#148;
</I>
	in Part&nbsp;II, Item&nbsp;7 of this report.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(f)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Comparable sales growth refers to the change in restaurant sales in one period from the same prior year period for restaurants that have been opened for thirteen months or longer.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(g)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Tim Hortons 2014 annual figures are shown for informational purposes only.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<A NAME="D294138D10K_HTM_TX294138_11">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;7.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations
</I>
</B>
<B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	You should read the following discussion together with Part&nbsp;II, Item&nbsp;6 &#147;Selected Financial Data&#148; of our Annual Report
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 (our &#147;Annual Report&#148;) and our audited Consolidated Financial Statements and the related notes thereto included in Part II, Item&nbsp;8 &#147;Financial Statements and Supplementary Data&#148; of our
	Annual Report.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	The following discussion includes information regarding future financial performance and plans, targets,
	aspirations, expectations, and objectives of management, which constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 and forward-looking information within the meaning of the Canadian
	securities laws as described in further detail under &#147;Special Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements&#148; that is set forth below.&nbsp;Actual results may differ materially from the results discussed in the forward-looking statements
	because of a number of risks and uncertainties, including the matters discussed in the &#147;Special Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements&#148; below.&nbsp;In addition, please refer to the risks set forth under the caption &#147;Risk
	Factors&#148; included in our Annual Report for a further description of risks and uncertainties affecting our business and financial results. Historical trends should not be taken as indicative of future operations and financial results. Other than
	as required under the U.S. Federal securities laws or the Canadian securities laws, we do not assume a duty to update these
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	forward-looking
</FONT>
	statements, whether as a result of new information, subsequent events
	or circumstances, changes in expectations or otherwise.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	We prepare our financial statements in accordance with accounting
	principles generally accepted in the United States (&#147;U.S. GAAP&#148; or &#147;GAAP&#148;). However, this Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations also contains certain
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	financial measures to assist readers in understanding our performance.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-GAAP
</FONT>
	financial measures either exclude or include amounts that are not reflected in the
	most directly comparable measure calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP. Where
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	financial measures are used, we have provided the most directly comparable measures calculated and presented in
	accordance with U.S. GAAP, a reconciliation to GAAP measures and a discussion of the reasons why management believes this information is useful to it and may be useful to investors.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Unless the context otherwise requires, all references in this section to the &#147;Company,&#148; &#147;we,&#148; &#147;us,&#148; or
	&#147;our&#148; are to Restaurant Brands International Inc. and its subsidiaries, collectively.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	28
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage29"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D294138D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Overview
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We are a Canadian corporation originally formed on August&nbsp;25, 2014 to serve as the indirect holding company for Tim Hortons and its
	consolidated subsidiaries and for Burger King and its consolidated subsidiaries. We are one of the world&#146;s largest quick service restaurant (&#147;QSR&#148;) companies with more than $24&nbsp;billion in system-wide sales and over 20,000
	restaurants in more than 100 countries and U.S. territories as of December&nbsp;31, 2016. Our
<I>
	Tim Hortons
</I>
	&reg; and
<I>
	Burger King
</I>
	&reg; brands have similar franchise business models with complementary daypart mixes. Our two iconic brands
	are managed independently while benefitting from global scale and sharing of best practices.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Tim Hortons restaurants are quick service
	restaurants with a menu that includes premium blend coffee, tea, espresso-based hot and cold specialty drinks, fresh baked goods, including donuts,
<I>
	Timbits
</I>
	&reg;, bagels, muffins, cookies and pastries, grilled paninis, classic sandwiches,
	wraps, soups and more. Burger King restaurants are quick service restaurants that feature flame-grilled hamburgers, chicken and other specialty sandwiches, french fries, soft drinks and other affordably-priced food items.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have two operating and reportable segments: (1)&nbsp;Tim Hortons (&#147;TH&#148;) and (2)&nbsp;Burger King (&#147;BK&#148;). We generate
	revenue from four sources: (i)&nbsp;sales exclusive to Tim Hortons franchisees related to our supply chain operations, including manufacturing, procurement, warehousing and distribution, as well as sales to retailers; (ii)&nbsp;franchise revenues,
	consisting primarily of royalties based on a percentage of sales reported by franchise restaurants and franchise fees paid by franchisees; (iii)&nbsp;property revenues from properties we lease or sublease to franchisees; and (iv)&nbsp;sales at
	restaurants owned by us (&#147;Company restaurants&#148;).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Prior to 2015, the fiscal year of Tim Hortons ended on the Sunday nearest to
	December&nbsp;31, which was December&nbsp;28 in 2014. The 2015 fiscal year for Tim Hortons commenced on December&nbsp;29, 2014 and ended on December&nbsp;31, 2015. This change to a calendar fiscal year by Tim Hortons did not have a material impact
	on our results of operations or key financial measures.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Operating Metrics and Key Financial Measures
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We evaluate our restaurants and assess our business based on the following operating metrics and key financial measures:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	System-wide sales growth refers to the change in sales at all franchise restaurants and Company restaurants in one period from the same period in the prior year.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	System-wide sales represent sales at all franchise restaurants and Company restaurants. We do not record franchise sales as revenues; however, our franchise revenues include royalties based on a percentage of franchise
	sales. System-wide results are driven by our franchise restaurants, as approximately 100% of current Tim Hortons and Burger King system-wide restaurants are franchised.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Comparable sales growth refers to the change in restaurant sales in one period from the same prior year period for restaurants that have been open for thirteen months or longer.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Net restaurant growth (&#147;NRG&#148;) represents the opening of new restaurants during a stated period, net of closures (other than limited service kiosks).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Adjusted EBITDA, a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	measure, represents earnings (net income or loss) before interest, (gain) loss on early extinguishment of debt, taxes, depreciation and amortization,
	adjusted to exclude specifically identified items that management believes are not relevant to management&#146;s assessment of operating performance. See
<I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-GAAP
</FONT>
	Reconciliations
</I>
	.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	System-wide sales growth and comparable sales growth are measured on a constant currency basis, which means the results exclude the effect of
	foreign currency translation (&#147;FX Impact&#148;).&nbsp;For system-wide sales growth and comparable sales growth, we calculate FX Impact by translating prior year results at current year monthly average exchange rates. For items included in our
	results of operations, we calculate the FX Impact by translating current year results at prior year monthly average exchange rates. We analyze these operating metrics on a constant currency basis as this helps identify underlying business trends,
	without distortion from the effects of currency movements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	29
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage30"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D294138D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Recent Events and Factors Affecting Comparability
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Integration Costs
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection
	with the implementation of initiatives to integrate the back-office processes of TH and BK to enhance efficiencies, we incurred $16.4&nbsp;million related to these initiatives during 2016, primarily consisting of professional fees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Tim Hortons Acquisition
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have
	consolidated the results of operations of Tim Hortons commencing on the acquisition date of December&nbsp;12, 2014, and the changes in our results of operations for 2015 as compared to 2014 are largely driven by the inclusion of the results of
	operations of TH for a full year in 2015 compared to the period of December&nbsp;12, 2014 through December&nbsp;28, 2014 in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	TH Transaction
	and Restructuring Costs
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection with the Transactions &#150; see Note 1 to the accompanying consolidated financial
	statements &#150; and a series of post-closing transactions during 2015 that resulted in changes to our legal and capital structure, we incurred certain
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-recurring
</FONT>
	selling, general and administrative
	expenses during 2015 and 2014, consisting of the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Financing, legal and advisory fees, share-based compensation expense due to accelerated vesting of equity awards as a result of the Transactions and integration costs related to a realignment of our global structure to
	better accommodate the needs of the combined business, totaling $83.4&nbsp;million and $108.7&nbsp;million during 2015 and 2014, respectively;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Severance benefits, other compensation costs and training expenses of approximately $31.1&nbsp;million and $16.3&nbsp;million during 2015 and 2014, respectively, related to a restructuring plan we implemented following
	the Transactions, which resulted in work force reductions throughout our TH business; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Financing, legal and advisory fees totaling $2.2&nbsp;million during 2015, in connection with issuing $1,250.0&nbsp;million of 4.625% first lien senior secured notes due January&nbsp;15, 2022 and entering into a first
	amendment to our credit agreement in May 2015.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Other Factors
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition to the impact of consolidating TH results of operations commencing on the acquisition date of December&nbsp;12, 2014 and TH
	transaction and restructuring costs, we also recorded losses on derivatives, incremental interest expense related to new borrowings and a loss on early extinguishment of debt in connection with the Transactions. See
<I>
	Results of Operations &#150;
	Other operating expenses (income), net, &#150; Interest expense, net
</I>
	and
<I>
	&#150; Loss on early extinguishment of debt
</I>
	.
</P>

</TD>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	(c)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	TH segment income for 2016 includes $12.2&nbsp;million of cash distributions from equity method investments. TH segment income for 2015 excludes $0.5&nbsp;million of acquisition accounting impact on cost of sales and
	includes $13.6&nbsp;million of cash distributions received from equity method investments. TH segment income for 2014 excludes $11.8&nbsp;million of acquisition accounting impact on cost of sales.
</TD>
</TR>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Comparable Sales Growth
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	TH global comparable sales growth of 2.5% for 2016 reflects growth in the breakfast, lunch, and dinner dayparts, with notable growth in the
	U.S.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	BK global comparable sales growth of 2.3% for 2016 reflects strength in Latin America and the Caribbean and Asia Pacific, partially
	offset by softness in Europe, the Middle East and Africa and the U.S. and Canada.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Sales and Cost of Sales
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Sales include TH supply chain sales and sales from Company restaurants. TH supply chain sales represent sales of products, supplies and
	restaurant equipment, other than equipment sales related to initial restaurant establishment or renovations that are shipped directly from our warehouses or by third-party distributors to restaurants or retailers, as well as sales to retailers.
	Sales from Company restaurants, including sales by our consolidated TH Restaurant VIEs (see Note 2 to the accompanying consolidated financial statements for additional information on Restaurant VIEs), represent restaurant-level sales to our guests.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cost of sales includes costs associated with the management of our TH supply chain, including cost of goods, direct labor and
	depreciation, as well as the cost of goods delivered by third-party distributors to the restaurants for which we manage the supply chain logistics, and for products sold through retailers. Cost of sales also includes food, paper and labor costs of
	Company restaurants, which are principally costs incurred by our consolidated TH Restaurant VIEs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016, the increase in sales was
	driven by a $102.8&nbsp;million increase in our TH segment, partially offset by a $1.9&nbsp;million decrease in our BK segment and a $65.2&nbsp;million unfavorable FX Impact. The increase in our TH segment was driven primarily by a
	$194.8&nbsp;million increase in our supply chain sales as a result of system-wide sales growth of 5.2% and an increase in retail sales. These factors were partially offset by a $92.0&nbsp;million decrease in our TH Company restaurant revenue
	resulting from the conversion of Restaurant VIEs to franchise restaurants.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015, the increase in sales was driven primarily by the
	inclusion of $2,074.3&nbsp;million of TH sales for a full year compared to $92.8&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016, the decrease in cost
	of sales was driven primarily by a $28.9&nbsp;million decrease in our TH segment, a $1.3&nbsp;million decrease in our BK segment and a $52.0&nbsp;million favorable FX Impact. The decrease in our TH segment was driven primarily by a
	$68.6&nbsp;million decrease in Company restaurant cost of sales, primarily from the conversion of Restaurant VIEs to franchise restaurants. This factor was partially offset by an increase in TH supply chain cost of sales driven by the increase in
	supply chain sales described above, net of supply chain cost savings derived from effective cost management.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	32
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage33"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D294138D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015, the increase in cost of sales was driven primarily by the inclusion of
	$1,728.1&nbsp;million of TH cost of sales for a full year compared to $92.1&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Franchise and Property
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Franchise and property revenues consist primarily of royalties earned on franchise sales, rents from real estate leased or subleased to
	franchisees, franchise fees, revenues derived from equipment packages at establishment of a restaurant and in connection with renewal or renovation, and other revenue. Franchise and property expenses consist primarily of depreciation of properties
	leased to franchisees, rental expense associated with properties subleased to franchisees, costs of equipment packages sold at establishment of a restaurant and in connection with renewal or renovation, amortization of franchise agreements and bad
	debt expense (recoveries).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016, the increase in franchise and property revenues was driven by a $73.5&nbsp;million increase in
	our BK segment and a $33.4&nbsp;million increase in our TH segment, partially offset by a $49.0&nbsp;million unfavorable FX Impact. The increase in our BK segment was primarily due to a $61.5&nbsp;million increase in royalties, driven by NRG and
	comparable sales growth, and a $16.2&nbsp;million increase in franchise fees and other revenue, driven by an increase in initial franchise fees and renewal franchise fees. The increase in our TH segment was primarily due to a $23.2&nbsp;million
	increase in royalties, driven by NRG and comparable sales growth, and a $16.2&nbsp;million increase in property revenues, driven by new leases and subleases associated with additional restaurants leased or subleased to franchisees as a result of
	converting Restaurant VIEs to franchise restaurants. These factors were partially offset by a $6.0&nbsp;million decrease in franchise fees and other revenue, driven by a decrease in sales of equipment packages.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015, the increase in franchise and property revenues was driven by the inclusion of $882.6&nbsp;million of TH franchise and property
	revenues for a full year compared to $50.8&nbsp;million in 2014 and an $89.1&nbsp;million increase in BK franchise and property revenues, partially offset by a $69.1&nbsp;million unfavorable FX Impact. The increase in our BK segment was primarily
	due to a $75.6&nbsp;million increase in royalties, driven by NRG and comparable sales growth, and a $13.7&nbsp;million increase in franchise fees and other revenue, driven primarily by an increase in renewal franchise fees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016, the decrease in franchise and property expenses was driven by a $34.0&nbsp;million decrease in our TH segment, a
	$3.7&nbsp;million decrease in our BK segment and an $11.4&nbsp;million favorable FX Impact. The decrease in our TH segment was driven primarily by a decrease in the costs related to sales of equipment packages and a decrease in bad debt expense. The
	decrease in our BK segment was driven primarily by a decrease in rent expense related to leases that were assigned to franchisees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During
	2015, the increase in franchise and property expenses was driven primarily by the inclusion of $360.7&nbsp;million of TH franchise and property expenses for a full year compared to $26.1&nbsp;million in 2014, partially offset by a $5.6&nbsp;million
	decrease in our BK segment, primarily related to a decrease in property expenses, and $4.8&nbsp;million favorable FX Impact.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_11"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>

	Administrative Expenses

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	NM &#150; Not Meaningful
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Segment selling, general and administrative expenses (&#147;Segment SG&amp;A&#148;) include segment selling expenses, which consist primarily
	of Company restaurant advertising fund contributions, and segment general and administrative expenses, which are comprised primarily of salary and employee-related costs for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-restaurant
</FONT>
	employees,
	professional fees, information technology systems and general overhead for our corporate offices.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	33
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage34"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D294138D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016, TH Segment SG&amp;A decreased primarily due to a decrease in salaries and benefits,
	a decrease in selling expenses as a result of a decrease in advertising fund contributions driven by a decrease in the number of Restaurant VIEs from the prior year period and favorable FX Impact. During 2015, TH Segment SG&amp;A increased primarily
	due to the inclusion of $93.2&nbsp;million of TH Segment SG&amp;A expenses for a full year in 2015 compared to $6.6&nbsp;million in 2014. During 2015, BK Segment SG&amp;A decreased primarily due to favorable FX Impact.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016, the decrease in share-based compensation and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	incentive compensation expense was
	due primarily to a decrease of $10.6&nbsp;million related to the remeasurement of liability-classified stock options to fair value, and a decrease of $6.6&nbsp;million related to stock option modifications, partially offset by additional share-based
	awards granted during 2016. During 2015, we modified a portion of liability-classified awards that resulted in a change in classification of the awards from liability to equity and as such these modified awards are no longer being revalued after the
	modification date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015, the increase in share-based compensation and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	incentive
	compensation expense was primarily due to additional stock options granted during 2015, an increase of $4.0&nbsp;million in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	incentive compensation and an increase of $6.1&nbsp;million related to the
	remeasurement of awards to fair value that are liability-classified or granted to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-employees.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016, the increase in depreciation and amortization expense is primarily due to higher depreciation related to information technology
	capital expenditures during 2015. During 2015, the increase in depreciation and amortization expense is primarily due to the inclusion of the TH business for a full year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	(Income) Loss from Equity Method Investments
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	(Income) loss from equity method investments reflects our share of investee net income or loss,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	dilution gains or losses from changes in our ownership interests in equity method investees and basis difference amortization.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The change in (income) loss from equity method investments during 2016 was primarily driven by improved earnings for Carrols Restaurant Group,
	Inc., our largest equity method investment based on our carrying value, and Pangaea Foods (China) Holdings, Ltd.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The change in (income)
	loss from equity method investments during 2015 was primarily driven by losses for Carrols Restaurant Group, Inc., partially offset by earnings from TH equity method investments for a full year compared to a $0.3&nbsp;million loss in 2014.
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net losses on disposal of assets, restaurant closures and refranchisings represent sales of properties and
	other costs related to restaurant closures and refranchisings. Gains and losses recognized in the current period may reflect certain costs related to closures and refranchisings that occurred in previous periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net losses on derivatives during 2015 is primarily due to changes in fair value related to interest rate swaps not designated for hedge
	accounting. These interest rate swaps were settled during May 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	34
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage35"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D294138D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2014, we entered into foreign currency forward and foreign currency option contracts to
	hedge our exposure to the volatility of the Canadian dollar in connection with the cash portion of the purchase price of the Tim Hortons acquisition. We recorded a net loss on derivatives of $133.0&nbsp;million related to the change in fair value on
	these instruments and an expense of $59.9&nbsp;million related to the premium on the foreign currency option contracts. These instruments were settled in the fourth quarter of 2014. Additionally, as a result of discontinuing hedge accounting on our
	interest rate caps and interest rate swaps, we recognized a loss of $34.5&nbsp;million related to the change in fair value related to both instruments and a net gain of $13.4&nbsp;million related to the reclassification of amounts from accumulated
	other comprehensive income (loss) (&#147;AOCI&#148;) into earnings related to both instruments. These instruments were settled in the fourth quarter of 2014. Additionally, during the fourth quarter of 2014 we entered into a series of
	forward-starting interest rate swaps to economically hedge the variability in the interest payments associated with our Term Loan Facility (as defined below) and recorded a gain of $88.9&nbsp;million related to the change in fair value related to
	these instruments. Lastly, during the fourth quarter of 2014 we entered into a series of cross-currency rate swaps to protect the value of our investments in our foreign operations against adverse changes in foreign currency exchange rates and
	recorded a loss of $165.8&nbsp;million related to the change in fair value on these instruments. See Note 11 to the accompanying consolidated financial statements for additional information about accounting for our derivative instruments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net losses (gains) on foreign exchange is primarily related to revaluation of foreign denominated assets and liabilities.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_13"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2016, interest expense, net decreased primarily in connection with a decrease in outstanding debt as a
	result of prepayments on our term loans in May 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015, interest expense, net increased primarily due to an increase in
	outstanding debt, partially offset by a reduction in our weighted average interest rate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Loss on Early Extinguishment of Debt
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015, we recorded a $40.0&nbsp;million loss on early extinguishment, which primarily reflects the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of unamortized debt issuance costs and unamortized discounts in connection with a prepayment of our Term Loan Facility (as defined below). Similarly, during 2014, we recorded a $155.4&nbsp;million
	loss on early extinguishment of debt related to a refinancing of a previous credit facility and redemptions of previously outstanding notes. The loss reflects the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of unamortized debt issuance costs
	and discounts, commitment fees associated with a bridge loan related to the acquisition of Tim Hortons, and the payment of premiums to redeem the notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Income Tax Expense
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our effective income
	tax rate was 20.3% in 2016 and 24.1% in 2015, primarily due to the mix of income from multiple tax jurisdictions and differing tax rules applicable to certain subsidiaries outside Canada. Our effective income tax rate was a negative 6.0% in 2014,
	primarily due to the impact of the Transactions, including
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-deductible
</FONT>
	transaction related costs, and the mix of income from multiple tax jurisdictions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Net Income (Loss)
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We reported net income
	of $955.9&nbsp;million for 2016 compared to net income of $511.7&nbsp;million in 2015, primarily as a result of a $474.5&nbsp;million increase in income from operations, the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-recurrence
</FONT>
	of
	$40.0&nbsp;million of loss on early extinguishment of debt and an $11.4&nbsp;million decrease in interest expense, net, partially offset by a $81.7&nbsp;million increase in income tax expense. The increase in operating income was driven primarily by
	a decrease in selling, general and administrative expenses, a decrease in other operating expenses (income), net, an increase in sales, a decrease in costs of sales, and a decrease in franchise and property expenses, as discussed above.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We reported net income of $511.7&nbsp;million during 2015, compared to a net loss of $269.3&nbsp;million during 2014, primarily as a result of
	a $1,011.1&nbsp;million increase in income from operations and a decrease of $115.4&nbsp;million in loss on early extinguishment of debt, partially offset by a $198.6&nbsp;million increase in interest expense, net and a $146.9&nbsp;million increase
	in income tax expense. The increase in income from operations was driven by an increase in sales, an increase in franchise and property revenues and a decrease in other operating expenses (income), net, partially offset by an increase in cost of
	sales, an increase in franchise and property expenses, and an increase in selling, general and administrative expenses, as discussed above.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	35
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D294138D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-GAAP
</FONT>
	Reconciliations
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The table below contains information regarding EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA, which are
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	measures,
	which do not have a standardized meaning under U.S. GAAP and may differ from similar captioned measures of other companies in our industry. We believe that these
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	measures are useful to investors in
	assessing our operating performance, as it provides them with the same tools that management uses to evaluate our performance and is responsive to questions we receive from both investors and analysts. By disclosing these
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	measures, we intend to provide investors with a consistent comparison of our operating results and trends for the periods presented. EBITDA is defined as earnings (net income or loss) before interest,
	(gain) loss on early extinguishment of debt, taxes, and depreciation and amortization and is used by management to measure operating performance of the business. Adjusted EBITDA is defined as EBITDA excluding the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	impact of share-based compensation and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	incentive compensation expense and (income) loss from equity method investments, net of cash distributions
	received from equity method investments, as well as other operating expenses (income), net. Other specifically identified costs associated with
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-recurring
</FONT>
	projects are also excluded from Adjusted EBITDA,
	including acquisition accounting impact on cost of sales, Tim Hortons transaction and restructuring costs and integration costs, each of which is associated with the acquisition of Tim Hortons. Adjusted EBITDA is used by management to measure
	operating performance of the business, excluding these
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	and other specifically identified items that management believes are not relevant to management&#146;s assessment of operating performance or the
	performance of an acquired business. Adjusted EBITDA, as defined above, also represents our measure of segment income.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(a)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Represents (i) (income) loss from equity method investments and (ii)&nbsp;cash distributions received from our equity method investments. Cash distributions received from our equity method investments are included in
	segment income.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The increase in Adjusted EBITDA for 2016 reflects increases in segment income in our TH and BK segments.
	The increase in Adjusted EBITDA for 2015 primarily reflects consolidation of TH for a full year in 2015 and, to a lesser extent, an increase in segment income in our BK segment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The increase in EBITDA for 2016 is primarily due to increases in segment income in our TH and BK segments, the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-recurrence
</FONT>
	of TH transaction and restructuring costs, favorable results from other operating expenses (income), net, favorable results from the impact of equity method investments, and a decrease in
	share-based compensation and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	incentive compensation, partially offset by integration costs recognized in the current period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The increase in EBITDA for 2015 primarily reflects consolidation of TH for a full year in 2015, an increase in BK segment income, a decrease
	in other operating expenses (income), net, a decrease in TH transaction and restructuring costs and a decrease in acquisition accounting impact on cost of sales, partially offset by an increase in share-based compensation and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	incentive compensation expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	36
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage37"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D294138D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our primary sources of liquidity are cash on hand, cash generated by operations and borrowings available under our Revolving Credit Facility
	(as defined below). We have used, and may in the future use, our liquidity to make required interest and/or principal payments, to pay dividends on Preferred Shares (as defined below), to repurchase our common shares, to repurchase Class&nbsp;B
	exchangeable limited partnership units (&#147;Partnership exchangeable units&#148;), to voluntarily prepay and repurchase our or one of our affiliate&#146;s outstanding debt, to fund our investing activities and to pay dividends on our common shares
	and distributions on the Partnership exchangeable units. As a result of our borrowings, we are highly leveraged. Our liquidity requirements are significant, primarily due to debt service and the cash dividend requirements of our Preferred Shares.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, we had cash and cash equivalents of $1,460.4&nbsp;million and working capital of $886.3&nbsp;million. In
	addition, at December&nbsp;31, 2016, we had borrowing availability of $498.5&nbsp;million under our Revolving Credit Facility. Based on our current level of operations and available cash, we believe our cash flow from operations, combined with
	availability under our Revolving Credit Facility, will provide sufficient liquidity to fund our current obligations, dividends on Preferred Shares, debt service requirements and capital spending over the next twelve months.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, approximately 5% of our consolidated cash and cash equivalents balances were held in tax jurisdictions other than
	Canada and the U.S. Undistributed earnings of our foreign subsidiaries for periods prior to the Transactions are considered indefinitely reinvested for U.S. income tax purposes. Subsequent to the Transactions, we record a deferred tax liability for
	earnings of foreign subsidiaries with U.S. parent companies when such amounts are not considered permanently reinvested and would be subject to tax in the U.S. upon repatriation of cash.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On August&nbsp;2, 2016, our board of directors approved a share repurchase authorization wherein RBI may purchase up to $300.0&nbsp;million of
	our common shares through July 2021. Repurchases under the Company&#146;s new authorization will be made in the open market or through privately negotiated transactions. In connection with the share repurchase authorization, on August&nbsp;4, 2016
	we announced that the Toronto Stock Exchange (the &#147;TSX&#148;) had accepted the notice of our intention to commence a normal course issuer bid. Under this normal course issuer bid, we are permitted to repurchase up to 18,085,962 common shares
	for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-year
</FONT>
	period commencing on August&nbsp;8, 2016 and ending on August&nbsp;7, 2017, or earlier if we complete the repurchases prior to such date. Share repurchases under the normal course issuer bid
	will be made through the facilities of the TSX, the New York Stock Exchange (the &#147;NYSE&#148;) and/or other exchanges and alternative Canadian or foreign trading systems, if eligible, or by such other means as may be permitted by the TSX and/or
	the NYSE under applicable law. Shareholders may obtain a copy of the notice, free of charge, by contacting the Company. As of the date of this report, there have been no share repurchases under the normal course issuer bid.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Debt Instruments and Debt Service Requirements
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Our long-term debt is comprised primarily of borrowings under our Credit Facilities, amounts outstanding under our 2015 Senior Notes, 2014
	Senior Notes and Tim Hortons Notes (each as defined below), and obligations under capital leases. For further information about our long-term debt, see Note 8 to the accompanying consolidated financial statements included in Part II, Item 8
	&#147;Financial Statements and Supplementary Data&#148; of our Annual Report.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Credit Facilities
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, two of our subsidiaries (the &#147;Borrowers&#148;) have a senior secured term loan facility maturing on
	December&nbsp;12, 2021 (the &#147;Term Loan Facility&#148;) and a senior secured revolving credit facility of up to $500.0&nbsp;million of revolving extensions of credit outstanding at any time (including revolving loans, swingline loans and letters
	of credit) maturing on December&nbsp;12, 2019 (the &#147;Revolving Credit Facility&#148; and together with the Term Loan Facility, the &#147;Credit Facilities&#148;). The interest rate applicable to the Credit Facilities is, at our option, either
	(i)&nbsp;a base rate plus an applicable margin equal to 1.75% in respect of the Term Loan Facility and 2.00% in respect of the Revolving Credit Facility, or (ii)&nbsp;a Eurocurrency rate plus an applicable margin equal to 2.75% in respect of the
	Term Loan Facility and ranging from 2.50% to 3.00%, depending on our leverage ratio, in respect of the Revolving Credit Facility. Borrowings are subject to a floor of 2.00% in the case of the base rate and to a floor of 1.00% in the case of
	Eurocurrency rate. We may prepay the Term Loan Facility in whole or in part at any time. Additionally, subject to certain exceptions, the Term Loan Facility may be subject to mandatory prepayments using (i)&nbsp;proceeds from
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-ordinary
</FONT>
	course asset dispositions, (ii)&nbsp;proceeds from certain incurrences of debt or (iii)&nbsp;a portion of our annual excess cash flows based upon certain leverage ratios.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Funds available under the Revolving Credit Facility may be used to repay other debt, finance debt or share repurchases, to fund acquisitions
	or capital expenditures and for other general corporate purposes. We have a $125.0&nbsp;million letter of credit sublimit as part of the Revolving Credit Facility, which reduces our borrowing availability thereunder by the cumulative amount of
	outstanding letters of credit. We are also required to pay (i)&nbsp;letters of credit fees on the aggregate face amounts of outstanding letters of credit plus a fronting fee to the issuing bank and (ii)&nbsp;administration fees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	37
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage38"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D294138D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Obligations under the Credit Facilities are guaranteed on a senior secured basis, jointly and
	severally, by the direct parent company of one of the Borrowers and substantially all of its Canadian and U.S. subsidiaries, including Tim Hortons, Burger King and substantially all of their respective Canadian and U.S. subsidiaries (the
	&#147;Credit Guarantors&#148;). Amounts borrowed under the Credit Facilities are secured on a first priority basis by a perfected security interest in substantially all of the present and future property (subject to certain exceptions) of each
	Borrower and Credit Guarantor.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, there was $5,046.1&nbsp;million outstanding principal amount under the Term
	Loan Facility with an interest rate of 3.75%. The principal amount of the Term Loan Facility amortizes in quarterly installments equal to 0.25% of the aggregate principal amount of the Term Loan Facility (as of the May 2015 amendment), with the
	balance payable at maturity. Based on the amounts outstanding under the Term Loan Facility and the three-month LIBOR as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, subject to a floor of 1.00%, required debt service for the next twelve months is estimated to be
	approximately $191.6&nbsp;million in interest payments and $34.2&nbsp;million in principal payments. In addition, as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, net cash settlements that we expect to pay on our $2,500.0&nbsp;million interest rate swap are estimated
	to be approximately $23.4&nbsp;million for the next twelve months.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, we had no amounts outstanding under the
	Revolving Credit Facility, had $1.5&nbsp;million of letters of credit issued against the facility, and our borrowing availability was $498.5&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;17, 2017, we entered into the second amendment to our Credit Facilities (the &#147;Second Amendment&#148;). Under this Second
	Amendment, (i)&nbsp;the outstanding aggregate principal amount under our Term Loan Facility was decreased to $4,900.0&nbsp;million as a result of a repayment of $146.1&nbsp;million from cash on hand, (ii)&nbsp;the interest rate applicable to our
	Term Loan Facility was reduced to, at our option, either (a)&nbsp;a base rate plus an applicable margin equal to 1.25%, or (b)&nbsp;a Eurocurrency rate plus an applicable margin equal to 2.25%, (iii)&nbsp;the maturity of our Term Loan Facility was
	extended from December&nbsp;12, 2021 to February&nbsp;17, 2024, and (iv)&nbsp;the Borrowers and their subsidiaries were provided with additional flexibility under certain negative covenants, including incurrence of indebtedness, making of
	investments, dispositions and restricted payments, and prepayment of subordinated indebtedness. The Second Amendment does not contain any material changes to other terms of the Credit Facilities, except as described herein. We incurred approximately
	$14.1&nbsp;million in fees related to the refinancing and we also expect to recognize debt extinguishment costs in the first quarter of 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Senior
	Notes
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Borrowers are party to an indenture (the &#147;2015 Senior Notes Indenture&#148;) in connection with the issuance of
	$1,250.0&nbsp;million of 4.625% first lien senior notes due January&nbsp;15, 2022 (the &#147;2015 Senior Notes&#148;). The Borrowers are also party to an indenture (the &#147;2014 Senior Notes Indenture&#148;) in connection with the issuance of
	$2,250.0&nbsp;million of 6.00% second lien secured notes due April&nbsp;1, 2022 (the &#147;2014 Senior Notes&#148;). No principal payments are due on the 2015 Senior Notes or 2014 Senior Notes until maturity and interest is paid semi-annually.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Obligations under the 2015 Senior Notes and 2014 Senior Notes are guaranteed on a senior secured basis, jointly and severally, by the
	Borrowers and substantially all of the Borrowers&#146; Canadian and U.S. subsidiaries (the &#147;Note Guarantors&#148;). The 2015 Senior Notes are first lien senior secured obligations and rank equal in right of payment with all of the existing and
	future senior debt of the Borrowers and Note Guarantors, including borrowings and guarantees of the Credit Facilities. The 2014 Senior Notes are second lien senior secured obligations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our 2015 Senior Notes and 2014 Senior Notes may be redeemed in whole or in part, on or after October&nbsp;1, 2017, at the redemption prices
	set forth in the corresponding indenture, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, at the date of redemption. The 2015 Senior Note Indenture and 2014 Senior Note Indenture also contain optional redemption provisions related to tender offers, change
	of control and equity offerings, among others.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Based on the amounts outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2016, required debt service for the
	next twelve months on the 2015 Senior Notes and 2014 Senior Notes is $57.8&nbsp;million and $135.0&nbsp;million, respectively, in interest payments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Tim Hortons Notes
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Tim Hortons Notes
	comprise three series of senior notes: (i)&nbsp;C$48.0&nbsp;million of series 1 notes, due June&nbsp;1, 2017 bearing interest at 4.20%, (ii) C$2.6&nbsp;million of series 2 notes, due December&nbsp;1, 2023, bearing interest at 4.52%, and
	(iii)&nbsp;C$3.9&nbsp;million of series 3 notes, due April&nbsp;1, 2019, bearing interest at 2.85% (collectively, the &#147;Tim Hortons Notes&#148;). No principal payments are due until maturity. Based on the amounts outstanding at December&nbsp;31,
	2016, required debt service for the next twelve months on the Tim Hortons Notes is C$1.1&nbsp;million in interest payments and C$47.4&nbsp;million in principal payments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	38
</P>

	Table of Contents
